excuse bonds Aston Martin db5 in
Goldfinger contains probably the most
famous ejecta see in film history and
apparently it really worked well in one
car the film actually features two Aston
Martin's one was there to look beautiful
and to be driven on roads while the
second gimmick car was fitted with an
old ejector seat from a fighter plane
triggered by compressed air so did it
work well many years later two masters
students in the department of physics
and astronomy at the University of
Leicester published a paper on the force
exerted by the Goldfinger ejecta see
they came to the conclusion that when
ejecting someone from an Aston Martin
db5 the force and pressure required is
1930 Newtons or eight thousand eight
hundred seventy Pascal's although they
did assume the thing was ejected via a
hydraulic piston they compared this to
pressures and forces inside a typical
piston engine and concluded that James
Bond's getup was feasible and this is
backed up by Top Gear and Mythbusters -
when Top Gear tried it they kind of
freestyled a bit then had a budget of
300 quid ish and they threw in a ball
draw bullet shield paint guns and a
rocket Mythbusters got back to basics
though they copied the 1960s prop makers
and used compressed air to shoot the
seat and again they found it plausible a
stunt could work in real life I should
say don't try this at home
no really just this year a teenager
broke his back after trying out a
friend's homemade ejecta see powered by
a car airbag so how did the early
airplane ejector seats work well what do
you know
they were also powered by compressed air
today though ejector seats are more
likely to be powered by computers and
explosives oh and the pros tend to call
them ejection seats there's all sorts of
ways to activate your ejection seat in a
fighter plane some of via the
traditional
and others are triggered by pulling down
a protective face covering but you'll
have to forget the old gear stick
ejector button I'm afraid however you do
it though the second you trigger a
rejection an electric pulse triggers the
hatch or roof above you to be jettisoned
sensors all around the chair measure
speed and altitude and a central
processing unit determines how the seat
should blow then a rocket and explosive
power catapult or both together kick you
and your seat up and out don't panic
though some fighter jet chairs have
Rockets stabilizing systems that fire to
stop the chair spinning some the whole
sequence takes less than 1/10 of a
second then a few seconds after
rejecting the altitude sensor
automatically deploys your main
parachute with the seat belt ejected the
chair drops away cheers gravity a
survival kit is often included dangling
below you but there's no more support
from the sea for seconds after bailing
you're on your own alone and likely
terrified in the 1940s only about 50% of
ejections were successful today that's
up to 90% but ejecting is still a
dangerous maneuver if you leave a plane
traveling at close to the speed of sound
then you can have up to 20 G's of force
acting on your body that's 20 times
Earth's gravity in 1995 Captain Brian
Adele had to escape from his f15
traveling at near Mach 1 the speed of
sound the blood vessels in his face
burst his head inflated to the size of a
watermelon and his legs were so badly
injured that one leg would cover your
ears if you're a little bit squeamish
was only held on by his vein artery and
skin still he lived all thanks to the
quick action of his ejection seat

he was a civilian I need it was only
